an10.75:12.8.en: So, Ānanda, don’t be judgmental about people.

an10.75:12.10.en: Those who pass judgment on people harm themselves.

an10.75:12.11.pli: Ahaṁ vā, ānanda, puggalesu pamāṇaṁ gaṇheyyaṁ yo vā panassa mādiso.
an10.75:12.11.en: I, or someone like me, may pass judgment on people.

an10.75:15.2.pli: ahaṁ vā, ānanda, puggalesu pamāṇaṁ gaṇheyyaṁ yo vā panassa mādiso.
an10.75:15.2.en: I, or someone like me, may pass judgment on people.

an10.75:18.2.pli: ahaṁ vā, ānanda, puggalesu pamāṇaṁ gaṇheyyaṁ yo vā panassa mādiso.
an10.75:18.2.en: I, or someone like me, may pass judgment on people.

an10.75:21.2.pli: ahaṁ vā, ānanda, puggalesu pamāṇaṁ gaṇheyyaṁ yo vā panassa mādiso.
an10.75:21.2.en: I, or someone like me, may pass judgment on people.

an10.75:25.7.en: So, Ānanda, don’t be judgmental about people.

an10.75:25.9.en: Those who pass judgment on people harm themselves.

an10.75:25.10.pli: Ahaṁ vā, ānanda, puggalesu pamāṇaṁ gaṇheyyaṁ yo vā panassa mādiso.
an10.75:25.10.en: I, or someone like me, may pass judgment on people.

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 10.75
8. If You Want
With Migasālā

mn54:3.11.pli: “Tathā hi pana me, bho gotama, sabbe kammantā paṭikkhittā, sabbe vohārā samucchinnā”ti.
mn54:3.11.en: “Master Gotama, it’s because I have refused all work and cut off all judgments.”

mn54:3.12.pli: “Yathā kathaṁ pana te, gahapati, sabbe kammantā paṭikkhittā, sabbe vohārā samucchinnā”ti?
mn54:3.12.en: “Householder, in what way have you refused all work and cut off all judgments?”

mn54:3.14.pli: Evaṁ kho me, bho gotama, sabbe kammantā paṭikkhittā, sabbe vohārā samucchinnā”ti.
mn54:3.14.en: That’s how I have refused all work and cut off all judgments.”

mn54:3.15.pli: “Aññathā kho tvaṁ, gahapati, vohārasamucchedaṁ vadasi, aññathā ca pana ariyassa vinaye vohārasamucchedo hotī”ti.
mn54:3.15.en: “The cutting off of judgments as you describe it is one thing, householder, but the cutting off of judgments in the noble one’s training is quite different.”

mn54:3.16.pli: “Yathā kathaṁ pana, bhante, ariyassa vinaye vohārasamucchedo hoti?
mn54:3.16.en: “But what, sir, is cutting off of judgments in the noble one’s training?

mn54:4.2.pli: “aṭṭha kho ime, gahapati, dhammā ariyassa vinaye vohārasamucchedāya saṁvattanti.
mn54:4.2.en: “Householder, these eight things lead to the cutting off of judgments in the noble one’s training.

mn54:4.12.pli: Ime kho, gahapati, aṭṭha dhammā saṅkhittena vuttā, vitthārena avibhattā, ariyassa vinaye vohārasamucchedāya saṁvattantī”ti.
mn54:4.12.en: These are the eight things—stated in brief without being analyzed in detail—that lead to the cutting off of judgments in the noble one’s training.”

mn54:14.1.pli: Ime kho, gahapati, aṭṭha dhammā saṅkhittena vuttā, vitthārena vibhattā, ye ariyassa vinaye vohārasamucchedāya saṁvattanti;
mn54:14.1.en: These are the eight things—stated in brief and analyzed in detail—that lead to the cutting off of judgments in the noble one’s training.

mn54:14.2.pli: na tveva tāva ariyassa vinaye sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ vohārasamucchedo hotī”ti.
mn54:14.2.en: But just this much does not constitute the cutting off of judgments in each and every respect in the noble one’s training.”

mn54:14.3.pli: “Yathā kathaṁ pana, bhante, ariyassa vinaye sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ vohārasamucchedo hoti?
mn54:14.3.en: “But, sir, how is there the cutting off of judgments in each and every respect in the noble one’s training?

mn54:25.1.pli: Ettāvatā kho, gahapati, ariyassa vinaye sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ vohārasamucchedo hoti.
mn54:25.1.en: That’s how there is the cutting off of judgments in each and every respect in the noble one’s training.

mn54:25.3.pli: yathā ariyassa vinaye sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ vohārasamucchedo hoti, api nu tvaṁ evarūpaṁ vohārasamucchedaṁ attani samanupassasī”ti?
mn54:25.3.en: Do you regard yourself as having cut off judgments in a way comparable to the cutting off of judgments in each and every respect in the noble one’s training?”

mn54:25.4.pli: “Ko cāhaṁ, bhante, ko ca ariyassa vinaye sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ vohārasamucchedo.
mn54:25.4.en: “Who am I compared to one who has cut off judgments in each and every respect in the noble one’s training?

an6.44:9.9.en: I, or someone like me, may pass judgment on people.

an6.44:16.9.en: I, or someone like me, may pass judgment on people.

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 6.44
5. About Dhammika
With Migasālā

mn18:8.1.en: “Mendicants, judgments driven by proliferating perceptions beset a person.

mn18:15.2.en: ‘Judgments driven by proliferating perceptions beset a person.

mn18:16.1.pli: Cakkhuñcāvuso, paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṁ, tiṇṇaṁ saṅgati phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā, yaṁ vedeti taṁ sañjānāti, yaṁ sañjānāti taṁ vitakketi, yaṁ vitakketi taṁ papañceti, yaṁ papañceti tatonidānaṁ purisaṁ papañcasaññāsaṅkhā samudācaranti atītānāgatapaccuppannesu cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu.
mn18:16.1.en: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a condition for feeling. What you feel, you perceive. What you perceive, you think about. What you think about, you proliferate. What you proliferate is the source from which judgments driven by proliferating perceptions beset a person. This occurs with respect to sights known by the eye in the past, future, and present.

mn18:16.6.pli: manañcāvuso, paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṁ, tiṇṇaṁ saṅgati phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā, yaṁ vedeti taṁ sañjānāti, yaṁ sañjānāti taṁ vitakketi, yaṁ vitakketi taṁ papañceti, yaṁ papañceti tatonidānaṁ purisaṁ papañcasaññāsaṅkhā samudācaranti atītānāgatapaccuppannesu manoviññeyyesu dhammesu.
mn18:16.6.en: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a condition for feeling. What you feel, you perceive. What you perceive, you think about. What you think about, you proliferate. What you proliferate is the source from which judgments driven by proliferating perceptions beset a person. This occurs with respect to thoughts known by the mind in the past, future, and present.

mn18:17.5.en: Where there is evidence of thought, it will be possible to discover evidence of being beset by judgments driven by proliferating perceptions.

mn18:17.14.en: Where there is evidence of thinking, it will be possible to discover evidence of being beset by judgments driven by proliferating perceptions.

mn18:18.5.pli: Vitakkapaññattiyā asati papañcasaññāsaṅkhāsamudācaraṇapaññattiṁ paññāpessatīti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
mn18:18.5.en: Where there is no evidence of thinking, it will not be possible to discover evidence of being beset by judgments driven by proliferating perceptions.

mn18:18.14.pli: Vitakkapaññattiyā asati papañcasaññāsaṅkhāsamudācaraṇapaññattiṁ paññāpessatīti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
mn18:18.14.en: Where there is no evidence of thinking, it will not be possible to discover evidence of being beset by judgments driven by proliferating perceptions.

sn3.7:1.3.pli: “idhāhaṁ, bhante, aḍḍakaraṇe nisinno passāmi khattiyamahāsālepi brāhmaṇamahāsālepi gahapatimahāsālepi aḍḍhe mahaddhane mahābhoge pahūtajātarūparajate pahūtavittūpakaraṇe pahūtadhanadhaññe kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ sampajānamusā bhāsante.
sn3.7:1.3.en: “Sir, when I’m sitting in judgment I see well-to-do aristocrats, brahmins, and householders—rich, affluent, and wealthy, with lots of gold and silver, lots of property and assets, and lots of money and grain. But they tell deliberate lies for the sake of sensual pleasures.

sn3.7:1.5.pli: ‘alaṁ dāni me aḍḍakaraṇena, bhadramukho dāni aḍḍakaraṇena paññāyissatī’”ti.
sn3.7:1.5.en: ‘Enough with passing judgment today. Now my dear son will be known by the judgments he makes.’”

snp4.12:17.1.en: Standing in judgment, measuring by their own standard,

snp4.12:17.3.en: But a person who has given up all judgments

ud7.7:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā attano papañcasaññāsaṅkhāpahānaṁ paccavekkhamāno nisinno hoti.
ud7.7:1.3.en: Now at that time the Buddha was sitting reviewing his own giving up of the judgments that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions.

ud7.7:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā attano papañcasaññāsaṅkhāpahānaṁ viditvā tāyaṁ velāyaṁ imaṁ udānaṁ udānesi:
ud7.7:2.1.en: Then, understanding his own giving up of the judgments that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

dn1:1.3.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ rattiyā paccūsasamayaṁ paccuṭṭhitānaṁ maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṁ sannipatitānaṁ ayaṁ saṅkhiyadhammo udapādi:
dn1:1.3.1.en: Then several mendicants rose at the crack of dawn and sat together in the pavilion, where the topic of judgmentalism came up:

dn1:1.4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tesaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ imaṁ saṅkhiyadhammaṁ viditvā yena maṇḍalamāḷo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Nisajja kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
dn1:1.4.1.en: When the Buddha found out about this discussion on judgmentalism among the mendicants, he went to the pavilion, where he sat on the seat spread out and addressed the mendicants,

mn89:13.3.pli: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, aḍḍakaraṇe nisinnassa antarantarā kathaṁ opātenti.
mn89:13.3.en: Yet when I’m sitting in judgment they interrupt me.

Shrines to the Teaching

dn14:1.37.3.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, bandhumā rājā atthakaraṇe nisinno vipassiṁ kumāraṁ aṅke nisīdāpetvā atthe anusāsati.
dn14:1.37.3.en: Then while King Bandhuma was sitting in judgment, he’d sit Prince Vipassī in his lap and explain the case to him.
